tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Sometimes Arya worries that none of this is real. That she is not truly in Storm’s End. That little Cassansa does not have...
caption:
Sometimes Arya worries that none of this is real. That she is not truly in Storm’s End. That little Cassansa does not have Gendry’s eyes and her nerve and both of their tempers, that she does not exist at all. That Torrhen does not truly rest in her arms and does not howl like a wolf when hungry. She worries that Gendry is not truly by her side. Some mornings she wakes up expecting to once again be in the cold, waiting for the dawn to come once more. Sometimes she wakes reaching for a sword she does not need. She has decided that even if none of this is real. That she is laying, dying, in the cold this is a better end than she could have hoped for. If this is a dream then she hopes to stay asleep. 

Post ASoIaF - Gendry and Arya are Lord and Lady of Storm’s End

summary: How I want Arya’s endgame to be: married Gendry and become the Lady of Storm’s End. Sailing west and live a  fulfilling life...
body: How I want Arya’s endgame to be: married Gendry and become the Lady of Storm’s End. Sailing west and live a  fulfilling life with her husband and children, living adventures and training with them.

summary: Calm as still water, she took the Bull by the arm and drew him back behind a tall flowering hedge.“What is it?” he asked. “What...
text:
Calm as still water, she took the Bull by the arm and drew him back behind a tall flowering hedge.“What is it?” he asked. “What are you doing? Let go.”
“Quiet as a shadow,” she whispered, pulling him down.

reblog.comment: a Clash of Kings

blog.name: gendrie
blog.title: fierce and terrible and hers
blog.description:
annalesa / 27 / pisces /
they would not make her yield

summary: starklings names:  brandon “bran” stark: mythic. brandon “bran the builder” stark is a legendary figure from the age of heroes....
body:
starklings names:

brandon “bran” stark:

mythic. brandon “bran the builder” stark is a legendary figure from the age of heroes. he is the founder of house stark and builder of winterfell as well as several other key structures (allegedly). its the classic name for stark kings. 

jon snow:

common. its like the jon smith of westeros. it doesnt get less noble than that. however his true name is aegon targaryen (I GUESS???) which has significant historical value. its a name for conquerors and kings. 

arya stark

unique. there’s only one arya stark. arya’s first name is taken from her great great grandmother who was a flint. but among the starks arya is the first to bear that name (officially). arya isn’t following in anyone’s footsteps. she’s one of a kind.

summary: And, girl. "M'lord." Lowborn girls say "m'lord," not "my lord." If you're going to pose as a commoner, you should do it...
caption: And, girl. “M'lord.” Lowborn girls say “m'lord,” not “my lord.” If you’re going to pose as a commoner, you should do it properly. My mother served Lady Dustin for many years, my lord. She taught me how to speak proper- properly.

tags: i have not thought about chess this much in F O R E V E R lol
all the typos in this post are why i am not allowed to make posts on my phone..
TELL ME IF YOU SEE ANY!
summary: Castling the King...  Protecting the king is the main goal in any chess strategy, and it should therefore be a focus from the...
body:
Castling the King… 

Protecting the king is the main goal in any chess strategy, and it should therefore be a focus from the opening sequence. In the beginning of the game, the king is somewhat exposed in the middle of the board. Therefore, measures must be taken to reduce his vulnerability. One of the most popular and most effective opening sequences is referred to as “castling”:

Castling is a move in the game of chess involving a player’s king and either of the player’s original rooks. It is the only move in chess in which a player moves two pieces in the same move, and it is the only move aside from the knight’s move where a piece can be said to “jump over” another. Castling consists of moving the king two squares towards a rook on the player’s first rank (the row closest to them) then moving the rook to the square over which the king crossed. (x)

Castling is an important goal in the opening, because it serves two valuable purposes:

  1. it moves the king into a safer position away from the center of the board
  2. it moves the rook to a more active position in the center of the board

A rook can movie horizontally or vertically, through any number of unoccupied squares, and have the potential to control/check entire ranks at one time. Additionally, a rook can potentially land on every square on the board and protect/attack unencumbered stretches on two planes at once; more squares, more ranks, more power. As with captures by other pieces, the rook captures by occupying the square on which the enemy piece sits. The rook’s defensive and attacking power, along with it’s wide range of abilities, is one of the things that makes the rook the second most valuable player on the board…

This is why, when considering the Starks as Players, I see Arya as a rook as opposed to a knight… The knight does have special abilities such as being able to “jump” other pieces and avoid standard capture. However, a knight is only allowed to move 2 squares at a time. This limitation in it’s mobility has a few effects on a knight’s overall value:

  1. at the height of it’s power a knight can only ever attack 8 squares- typically this makes the knight most useful only in close proximity battle situations.
  2. it makes the knight “slow”- due to its movement pattern it can take up to six moves to get from a corner square to a specific square on the other side of the board
  3. it makes if very difficult for knights to “cooperate” with other pieces- i.e. a knight could not specifically work in tandem with a king during the opening or the endgame.

Knights are also subject to other limitations that rooks are not. For example, a knight also has a special condition that if it retreats from one square, it cannot continue to attack or defend the squares it was attacking or defending before its retreat; a rook’s movements and attacking/defending abilities are not encumbered by the same limitation. Essentially, like the knights of Westeros, the knights on a chessboard are powerful only in specific situations. Knights are great, but rooks are have more strategic clout and and more valuable for the endgame.

For me, Arya is far more powerful, capable, and valueable than a standard knight at this point. She has a variety of abilities that make her formidable player: she is quick, and strategic, and disciplined. She excels in sword fighting and other physical combat techniques. She wil be indispensable in the areas of espionage and subterfuge; she literally has the ability to change her appearance and assume another identity. And she has (or at least WILL HAVE) an entire wolf pack following her lead through Nymeria. The powers and abilities of a rook go a long way in making them a valuable player and protecting the king through out the game as well as in the endgame.

The king and the rook, the only two players who can move together in tandem, make an incredibly effective strategic pair…

(*gif by @stark)

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
Bran: Well, some of you will probably die this season.
Sansa: Some of us? You're not included?
Bran: Precisely.
Jon: Explain,...
body:
Bran: Well, some of you will probably die this season.

Sansa: Some of us? You’re not included?

Bran: Precisely.

Jon: Explain, please.

Bran: Because they’re called the white WALKERS.

Arya: he does have a point.

summary: I'm rereading the series and it struck me that Arya thought that she would be "strong like Robb" at least two times (when...
question: I'm rereading the series and it struck me that Arya thought that she would be "strong like Robb" at least two times (when talking to Ned when he gave the lone wolf speech and when she was at harrenhall).  I love how Arya looked up to both her big brothers.  She had a great relationship with both of them but in different ways (and with Bran and Rickon too).  I love how Bran, Arya, Sansa, Jon and Theon all looked up to Robb.
answer:
God I know. Even in the show you can tell how much she looked up to Robb, the way she spoke about him to Tywin when she was pretending to be a common girl from the North, and he asked her what the North thought of Robb.

When I watched The Red Wedding I messaged everyone I know who watches the show and was like “The worst part of this whole thing is that Arya was right fucking there, she hasn’t seen her family in years, and you can tell how much it means to her, and she’s finally closer to them than she’s been in years, and she doesn’t even get to say goodbye to her mother or her brother.”

Also tag yourself, i’m everyone looking up to Robb.

summary: Can someone please talk about how Jon and Arya flank Sansa, like she's the one to protect? Literally Jon walks up from the...
body: Can someone please talk about how Jon and Arya flank Sansa, like she’s the one to protect? Literally Jon walks up from the middle, then he ends up on the side? It looks like they’re foreshadowing a potential QitN, like he’s giving the the position up to her.
